Award.AwardTitle: Chalcogenides Superconductors: Nonconventional Superconductivity in New Phases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Superconductivity is a quantum phenomenon in which, below a critical temperature, the electrical resistance completely vanishes. Conventional superconductors, discovered over 100 years ago, are composed of simple metals, and the phenomenon was completely explained about 50 years ago. The applications of superconductors include the ability to transmit many times more power than metals at the same temperature and cross-sectional area. However, conventional superconductors are limited in that they have to be cooled to very low temperatures. More importantly, they are limited in the magnitude of current they can transmit (critical current) in an external magnetic field (critical field). Over the years, conventional superconductors have been improved and new areas have been discovered that enhanced these current carrying capabilities in a magnetic field, making possible high-field research magnets and applications that include MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). Enter the discoveries of unconventional superconductors about 40 years ago, followed by the discovery of high-temperature superconductors 30 years ago, these materials which are not good metals above their critical temperature, are not completely understood, but many of these intriguing materials can transmit much more current in extremely high magnetic fields than conventional superconductors. Not only can the applications of unconventional superconductors be transformative, but the fundamental physics explaining their normal and superconducting properties remains elusive over all of this time. With the support of the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program, the research group will study unconventional superconductor phases that include metals such as niobium and tantalum, as well as the nonmetallic elements sulfur, selenium or tellurium.

Technical Abstract
Transition metal chalcogenides comprise superconducting phases with high critical temperatures, such as iron and molybdenum chalcogenides. The research effort focuses on new ternary and quaternary niobium and tantalum chalcogenides, with some of these phases showing unconventional superconductivity with very large critical fields. At the core of this behavior are interactions between electron charge, electron spin and the lattice (the crystal structure). Critically important are the synthesis and growth of high quality samples for a detailed understanding of structure-property relationships. Structural characterization using diffraction techniques will be combined with investigations of physical properties, including magnetic susceptibility, electronic transport properties and optical properties. Furthermore, tuning of the physical properties by a combination of chemical substitutions and stoichiometry variations are explored. Crystal growth of such phases is well matched to the areas delineated in the National Academy of Sciences report "Frontiers in Crystalline Matter: From Discovery to Technology," which focuses on the opportunities for discovery and growth of crystalline matter in the US. This research is a highly interdisciplinary activity that requires a variety of skills. Training of students in the art and science of crystal growth and characterization of materials at undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate levels trains the next generation of scientists and engineers active in this field and builds the highly skilled workforce needed to address tomorrow's challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transition metal chalcogenides, compounds consisting of transition metals and sulfur, selenium or tellurium, have been associated with interesting properties, among them superconductivity, intercalation behavior, charge density waves, and semiconducting properties. In this project, we focused on a particular compound, Nb2PdxSe5, a metallic system with a variable palladium content. While previous synthesis efforts yielded samples within a very narrow stoichiometry range only, we developed a synthesis method where a larger composition range for palladium could be investigated. Structurally, there are two palladium atoms in a unit cell, but only one of them is variable. We found that this palladium atom is crucial to the stability of the compound and profoundly affects the electronic properties. In particular, the variable palladium atom is responsible for linking up units of Nb4PdSe5, forming a stable network (see the high resolution electron microscope image). This palladium atom can be considered as an intercalating atom that does not change the structure of the compound, but affects the electronic properties profoundly. 

The variable palladium stoichiometry allows to tune the electronic behavior of Nb2PdxSe5, so that superconductivity is found in a total palladium stoichiometry range of x=0.808 to 0.892 (corresponding to Pd2 site occupancy 0.616 to 0.783). At a total palladium content of x=0.793 (Pd2 occupancy 0.585), a superconducting transition begins at T=0.57 K, but remains incomplete with a resistivity plateau observed at temperatures below T=0.10 K, and for Pd x<0.75 (Pd2 occupancy 0.50) no superconductivity is observed and at very low temperatures, the material becomes more insulating.  Superconductivity occurs with a maximum temperature, Tc, of 5.01K for a total palladium stoichiometry of x=0.813 (Pd2=0.625). This material is able to maintain superconductivity even in a large magnetic field, about four times larger than expected based on the BCS theory of superconductivity. Such behavior indicates that the superconducting electron interactions are different than in the BCS theory.

In addition, the puzzling fact that only limited ranges for the variable palladium content exist led to the realization that the variable palladium atoms develop various ordered arrangements for each stoichiometry range. This was further supported by computational modeling of the palladium intercalation, indicating that the additional ordering increases the stability of the compound.

One graduate and several undergraduate students were involved in this project. The graduate student will obtain the PhD degree on the basis of the research carried out within this project. Additionally, undergraduate students who assisted the graduate student in the research efforts experienced Materials Research at an early time in their careers. The collaborative nature of the research proposed gave students ample opportunity to interact and work together on projects of fundamental interest, with the collaboration providing access to state-of-the-art characterization equipment.

Training of students in the art and science of crystal growth and characterization of materials at undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate levels will yield the next generation of scientists active in the field of materials science, an important area for the competitiveness of the USA.

FSU, and the FAMU-FSU College of Engineering are committed to developing excellence in teaching and training of undergraduate and graduate students, and this research enhanced and advanced these efforts.

In addition, we particpated in the annual Open House of the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory, demonstrating material applications in modern devices. In the last years, the Open House activities attracted in more than 10,000 visitors .


Last Modified: 10/23/2020
Modified by: Theo Siegrist

Images (1 of )
  • The superconducting transition temperature of Nb2PdxSe5 as a function of palladium content. The highest transition temperature is at a palladium site occupancy of 0.65, giving a composition of Nb2Pd0.825Se5.
    J. Neu, Florida State University
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Theo Siegrist
    The superconducting transition temperature versus Palladium content in Nb2PdxSe5
  • Resistivity versus temperature for Nb2PdxSe5 with different palladium content. For low palladium content, insulating behavior is observed, whereas for higher palladium content, superconductivity sets in.
    J. Neu, Florida State University
    Theo Siegrist
    Resistivity of Nb2PdxSe5 with different Palladium Content
  • SciGirls Summer Camp Parti.cipants on a tour of the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory, led by the graduate student supported by this project.
    NHMFL
    Theo Siegrist
    SciGirls Tour at the national High magnetic Field Laboratory
  • Structure of Nb2PdxSe5, imaged using a High Resolution Microscope, The Nb4PdSe10 units run horizontal. The variable palladium runs vertical, and links up the Nb4PdSe10 units.
    Y. Xin, High Magnetic Field Laboratory
    Theo Siegrist
    High Resolution Electron Microscopy of the Structure of Nb2PdxSe5
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Transition metal chalcogenides, compounds consisting of transition metals and sulfur, selenium or tellurium, have been associated with interesting properties, among them superconductivity, intercalation behavior, charge density waves, and semiconducting properties. In this project, we focused on a particular compound, Nb2PdxSe5, a metallic system with a variable palladium content. While previous synthesis efforts yielded samples within a very narrow stoichiometry range only, we developed a synthesis method where a larger composition range for palladium could be investigated. Structurally, there are two palladium atoms in a unit cell, but only one of them is variable. We found that this palladium atom is crucial to the stability of the compound and profoundly affects the electronic properties. In particular, the variable palladium atom is responsible for linking up units of Nb4PdSe5, forming a stable network (see the high resolution electron microscope image). This palladium atom can be considered as an intercalating atom that does not change the structure of the compound, but affects the electronic properties profoundly. The variable palladium stoichiometry allows to tune the electronic behavior of Nb2PdxSe5, so that superconductivity is found in a total palladium stoichiometry range of x=0.808 to 0.892 (corresponding to Pd2 site occupancy 0.616 to 0.783). At a total palladium content of x=0.793 (Pd2 occupancy 0.585), a superconducting transition begins at T=0.57 K, but remains incomplete with a resistivity plateau observed at temperatures below T=0.10 K, and for Pd x<0.75 (Pd2 occupancy 0.50) no superconductivity is observed and at very low temperatures, the material becomes more insulating. Superconductivity occurs with a maximum temperature, Tc, of 5.01K for a total palladium stoichiometry of x=0.813 (Pd2=0.625). This material is able to maintain superconductivity even in a large magnetic field, about four times larger than expected based on the BCS theory of superconductivity. Such behavior indicates that the superconducting electron interactions are different than in the BCS theory. In addition, the puzzling fact that only limited ranges for the variable palladium content exist led to the realization that the variable palladium atoms develop various ordered arrangements for each stoichiometry range.
